'''Forrest Richard Betts''' (December 12, 1943 – April 18, 2024) was an American guitarist, singer, songwriter, composer and founding member of [[the Allman Brothers Band]]. He initially shared the band's signature dual [[lead guitar]] roles with band founder [[Duane Allman]], and assumed the solo lead after Allman's death in October of 1971.  As both a singer and composer as well, he was central to the group's greatest commercial success in the mid-1970s and was the writer and vocalist on the Allmans' hit single "[[Ramblin' Man (The Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]". 

Early in his career Betts was best noted for collaboration with Duane Allman,<ref name=Tdrozodowski>{{cite web|url=http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/Come%20and%20Go%20Blues_%20The%20Incredi|title=Come and Go Blues: The Incredible Guitarists of the Allman Brothers|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100126202416/http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Features/Come%20and%20Go%20Blues_%20The%20Incredi|archive-date=January 26, 2010}}</ref> the twosome introducing melodic twin guitar harmony and counterpoint, which, according to ''Guitar World'' "rewrote the rules for how two rock guitarists can work together, completely scrapping the traditional rhythm/lead roles to stand toe to toe".<ref name="GW July 2009">{{cite magazine|title=The Allman Brothers Band: The Road Goes on Forever|magazine=Guitar World|date=July 20, 2009|url=http://www.guitarworld.com/article/the_allman_brothers_band_the_road_goes_on_forever|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202053024/http://www.guitarworld.com/article/the_allman_brothers_band_the_road_goes_on_forever|archive-date=February 2, 2010}}</ref> Betts initially gained renown for his epic [[instrumental]], "[[In Memory of Elizabeth Reed]]", from the Band's second album, ''[[Idlewild South]]'', followed by his striking guitar duet-driven "[[Blue Sky (song)|Blue Sky]]", which not only was his first band vocal but signaled a dramatic new sound and potential direction for it.  

In the wake of Duane's death the group indeed followed both Betts' musical direction and band leadership, exploding into commercial success in 1973 upon the introduction of the [[Country music|Country]]-influenced ''[[Brothers and Sisters (album)|Brothers and Sisters]]'', and the chart success of its catchy Betts-written hits, exuberant "Ramblin' Man" and the melodic instrumental "[[Jessica (instrumental)|Jessica]]".

The band went through a hiatus in the late 1970s, during which time Betts, like many of the other band members, pursued a solo career and side projects under such names as Great Southern and The Dickey Betts Band.  The Allman Brothers reformed in 1979, with [[Dan Toler]] taking the second guitar role alongside Betts.  In 1982, it broke up a second time, during which break Betts formed the group [[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]], which lasted until 1984.  A third reformation occurred in 1989, with [[Warren Haynes]] then joining Betts on guitar. 

Betts was ousted from the band in 2000 over a conflict regarding his continued drug and alcohol abuse; he never played with them again, nor would he appear with other former band members for reunions or side projects. With the death of Betts on April 18, 2024, Jai Johanny "[[Jaimoe]]" Johanson is the last living founding member of the Allman Brothers Band.

He was inducted with the band into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 1995<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/the-allman-brothers-band/ |title=The Allman Brothers Band: inducted in 1995 | The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum |publisher=Rockhall.com |access-date=February 28, 2012 |archive-date=July 1, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120701000000/http://www.rockhall.com/inductees/the-allman-brothers-band/ |url-status=live }}</ref> and also won a best rock performance [[Grammy Award]] with the band for "Jessica" in 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1995&genre=All|title=1995 Grammy Award Winners|publisher=Grammy.com|access-date=November 18, 2012|archive-date=September 23, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923073524/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=&title=&year=1995&genre=All|url-status=live}}</ref> Betts was ranked No. 58 on ''Rolling Stone''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time list in 2003, and No. 61 on the list published in 2011.<ref name=RS931>{{cite magazine |title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time |magazine=Rolling Stone |issue=931 |date=September 22, 2003 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231/dickey-betts-19691231 |access-date=August 26, 2017 |archive-date=July 13, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120713073551/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-of-all-time-19691231/dickey-betts-19691231 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=RS1145>{{cite magazine|title=The 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time|magazine=Rolling Stone|issue=1145|date=November 23, 2011|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/dickey-betts-19691231|access-date=August 26, 2017|archive-date=July 18, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120718093137/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-guitarists-20111123/dickey-betts-19691231|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Early life ==
{{expand section|date=September 2024}}

Betts was born in [[West Palm Beach, Florida]], on December 12, 1943, and raised in [[Bradenton, Florida|Bradenton]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lcwXAAAAQBAJ&pg=PT69|title=Skydog: The Duane Allman Story|first=Randy|last=Poe|date=August 1, 2008|publisher=Hal Leonard Corporation|isbn=9781617134876}}</ref><ref name=NFMHOF>{{cite web|last1=Fitzgerald|first1=Michael|title=Betts, Dickey|url=http://nfmhof.com/2008/08/13/betts-dickey|publisher=North Florida Music Hall of Fame|access-date=August 3, 2014|date=August 13, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108154840/http://nfmhof.com/2008/08/13/betts-dickey|archive-date=November 8, 2014}}</ref> He grew up in a musical family listening to [[traditional bluegrass]], [[country music]] and [[Western swing]]. He started playing ukulele at the age of five and, as his hands got bigger, moved on to mandolin, banjo, and guitar.

==Career==
By the age of sixteen Betts was feeling the need for something "a little faster", and played in a series of rock bands on the Florida circuit, up the East Coast and into the Midwest.  In 1967 he formed the Second Coming in Florida with [[Berry Oakley]]. According to its composer, [[Rick Derringer]], the group called the Jokers referenced in "[[Rock and Roll, Hoochie Koo]]" was one of Betts' early groups of that name.<ref>Scott Freeman, ''Midnight Riders'', pp. 41–42</ref>

=== Early Allman Brothers Band years ===
In 1969, [[Duane Allman]], a veteran of the South's "Chitlin' Circuit" of roadhouses and small local venues who'd gone on to form several bands with recording contracts, was casting for talent to build another around.  A successful session player, he'd gained a deal with [[Southern soul]] impresario [[Phil Walden]], who planned to back a [[power trio]] featuring Allman. The ensuing Allman Brothers Band eventually grew to six members, including Duane's brother, organist, vocalist, and composer [[Gregg Allman|Gregg]], Betts, and bassist [[Berry Oakley]].{{cn|date=April 2024}} Duane, who later worked with famed British guitar virtuoso [[Eric Clapton]], earning notoriety for his standout playing on "[[Layla (song)|Layla]]'', the collaboration's signature hit, once said with typical modesty, "I'm the famous guitar player, but Dickey is the good one."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Alex |title=Dickey Betts, Fiery Guitarist With Allman Brothers Band, Dies at 80 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/18/arts/music/dickey-betts-dead.html |work=The New York Times |date=April 18, 2024 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |archive-date=April 19, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240419202131/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/04/18/arts/music/dickey-betts-dead.html |url-status=live }}</ref> 

After Allman's death in October 1971, Betts became the band's sole lead guitarist (with a pianist bringing the group back up to six members) and took on a greater singing, composing, and leadership role. Rushed into the role, he practiced [[slide guitar]] intensively in order to be able to cover the majority of Duane's parts. He wrote "[[Jessica (Allman Brothers Band song)|Jessica]]", inspired by his young daughter Jessica,<ref>{{Cite book|title=One Way Out: The Inside History of the Allman Brothers Band|first=Alan|last=Paul|year=2014|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-1250040497}}</ref>and the Allmans' biggest commercial hit, "[[Ramblin' Man (Allman Brothers Band song)|Ramblin' Man]]",<ref>{{cite web|url= https://rockcellarmagazine.com/dickey-betts-dies-allman-brothers-band-obituary/|title=Dickey Betts, Allman Brothers Co-Founder Who Wrote "Ramblin' Man," "Jessica" and More, Dies at 80|publisher=Rockcellarmagazine.com|date=April 18, 2024|accessdate=April 20, 2024}}</ref> for the Band's breakout commercial success, ''[[Brothers and Sisters (album)|Brothers and Sisters]]'', in 1974.

=== Solo career and later work ===
[[File:Dickey Betts (1974).jpg|thumb|Betts in 1974|244x244px]]
Betts's first solo album, ''[[Highway Call]]'', was released in 1974 and featured fiddle player [[Vassar Clements]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Highway Call – Dickey Betts, Richard Betts | Album | AllMus |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/highway-call-mw0000199122 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221022115912/https://www.allmusic.com/album/highway-call-mw0000199122 |archive-date=October 22, 2022 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> After the Allman Brothers fell apart in 1976, Betts released more albums, starting with ''[[Dickey Betts & Great Southern (album)|Dickey Betts & Great Southern]]'' in 1977, which included the song "Bougainvillea", co-written with future Hollywood star and then Florida transplant [[Don Johnson]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Dickey Betts & Great Southern – Dickey Betts & Great Southe |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/dickey-betts-great-southern-mw0000602906 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230909051526/https://www.allmusic.com/album/dickey-betts-great-southern-mw0000602906 |archive-date=September 9, 2023 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> In 1978 he released an album, ''[[Atlanta's Burning Down]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Atlanta's Burning Down – Dickey Betts | Album | AllMusic |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/atlantas-burning-down-mw0000049199 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221020100419/https://www.allmusic.com/album/atlantas-burning-down-mw0000049199 |archive-date=October 20, 2022 |access-date=April 19, 2024 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref>

The Allman Brothers reformed in 1979 for the album ''[[Enlightened Rogues]]'', with two members of Great Southern replacing Allman Brothers members who were unwilling to participate in the reunion: guitar player [[Dan Toler]] for pianist [[Chuck Leavell]], and bassist [[David Goldflies]] for bassist [[Lamar Williams]]. Several albums and personnel changes followed, until declining record and concert ticket sales, personnel issues, and management problems led the group to disband again in 1982.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 27, 2014 |title=History of the Allman Brothers Band |url=https://ultimateclassicrock.com/allman-brothers-band-history/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231003172943/https://ultimateclassicrock.com/allman-brothers-band-history/ |archive-date=October 3, 2023 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Ultimateclassicrock.com}}</ref>

Betts formed his own band, [[Betts, Hall, Leavell and Trucks]], where he was co-frontman along with former [[Wet Willie]] singer, saxophone, and harmonica player [[Jimmy Hall]]. Despite earning good notices, the group was unable to secure a recording contract and disbanded in 1984.<ref>{{Cite book |last1=Leavell |first1=Chuck |title=Between Rock And A Home Place |last2=Craig |first2=J. Marshall |publisher=Evergreen Arts |year=2004 |isbn=0-86554-975-3 |location=Dry Branch, Georgia |pages=260–264}} For the ending year, see {{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/101951915/lexington-herald-leader/ | title=David Goldflies' jazz vision | author-first=Walter | author-last=Tunis | newspaper=Lexington Herald-Leader | date=April 21, 1991 | pages=C1, C7 | via=Newspapers.com | access-date=May 21, 2022 | archive-date=May 20, 2022 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220520105254/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/101951915/lexington-herald-leader/ | url-status=live }}</ref> Betts  returned to his solo career performing live at smaller venues, and released the album ''Pattern Disruptive'' in 1989. When a one-off reunion tour was proposed in support of the Allman Brothers' ''[[Dreams (The Allman Brothers Band album)|Dreams]]'' box set, released in 1989 to commemorate the band's 20th anniversary, Betts's solo band again supplied the Allman Brothers' other lead guitarist, [[Warren Haynes]]. The success of the one-off tour resulted in a permanent reunion, which absorbed Betts's energies for the remainder of the 1990s. This band line-up released three studio albums between 1990 and 1994 and won the praise of the critics.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Elliott, Mike |date=July 20, 2020 |title=The Allman Brothers Band's 'Seven Turns' Turns 30 {{!}} Anniversary Retrospective |url=https://albumism.com/features/the-allman-brothers-band-seven-turns-turns-30-anniversary-retrospective |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220703150058/https://albumism.com/features/the-allman-brothers-band-seven-turns-turns-30-anniversary-retrospective |archive-date=July 3, 2022 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Albumism}}</ref>
[[File:Dickey Betts Pistoia Blues Festival 2008.jpg|left|thumb|243x243px|Betts in 2008]]
Betts was replaced on numerous Allman Brothers tour dates throughout the mid-to-late 1990s, for what were reported in the media as "personal reasons". While remaining active as a touring band, the Allman Brothers did not release another album of studio material after 1994's ''[[Where It All Begins]]'' for nine years, until ''[[Hittin' the Note]]'' in 2003. In 1994, Haynes and Allmans bassist Allen Woody formed [[Gov't Mule]] with former Dickey Betts Band drummer Matt Abts as a side project, and left the Allman Brothers for Gov't Mule full-time in 1997. Betts' last show with the Allman Brothers was at the Music Midtown Festival in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], on May 7, 2000.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Roger Catlin |date=May 25, 2000 |title=BETTS IS ANGRY AS ALLMANS DUMP HIM FROM TOUR |url=https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2000-05-25-0005251999-story.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190720154255/https://www.courant.com/news/connecticut/hc-xpm-2000-05-25-0005251999-story.html |archive-date=July 20, 2019 |access-date=February 3, 2021 |website=Courant.com}}</ref>

A breaking point was reached after that show and before the launch of the band's Summer Campaign Tour when the remaining original Allman Brothers members – Gregg Allman, Butch Trucks, and Jaimoe – suspended Betts.<ref name="ew">{{Cite magazine |last=Reese |first=Lori |date=May 18, 2000 |title=Brothers in Law |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85221,00.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021145418/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,85221,00.html |archive-date=October 21, 2012 |access-date=June 16, 2011 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> According to Betts, the band told him (reportedly via [[fax]]) to "get clean" (from alcohol and/or drugs). 

He was temporarily replaced for the 2000 tour by [[Jimmy Herring]], formerly of the [[Aquarium Rescue Unit]]. When Betts filed suit against the other three original Allmans, the separation turned into a permanent divorce.<ref>{{cite book |last=Allman |first=Gregg |title=My Cross To Bear |publisher=HarperCollins |year=2012}}{{p.|340}}</ref> Betts re-formed the Dickey Betts Band and toured that same summer. The band reassumed the name Dickey Betts & Great Southern and added Betts' son Duane (named after Duane Allman) on lead guitar. In 2005, Betts released the DVD ''Live from the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back Where It All Begins: Live at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame [Video] |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/back-where-it-all-begins-live-at-the-rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-video--mw0001020587 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=AllMusic}}</ref>

Although they had been separated personally and as musical bandmates for over 15 years, Betts and Gregg Allman became reconciled before Allman's death in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Ferris, Jedd |date=December 13, 2018 |title=ee Dickey Betts Talk Gregg Allman Reconciliation, Return to Touring |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-dan-rather-768633/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230606131632/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-dan-rather-768633/ |archive-date=June 6, 2023 |access-date=April 20, 2024 |publisher=Rolling Stone}}</ref>

Betts' final album release was ''Dickey Betts & Great Southern Official Bootleg Vol. 1'' (2021), a two-CD live album of performances from the 2000s.<ref>{{Cite news |date=April 24, 2021 |title=Dickey Betts Announces 'Dickey Betts & Great Southern Official Bootleg Vol. 1' |url=https://dickeybetts.com/dickey-betts-announces-dickey-betts-great-southern-official-bootleg-vol-1/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240109192901/https://dickeybetts.com/dickey-betts-announces-dickey-betts-great-southern-official-bootleg-vol-1/ |archive-date=January 9, 2024 |access-date=April 18, 2024 |work=Dickey Betts}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Betts was married five times, last to Donna, in 1989.<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dickey-betts-the-lost-allman-brother-121021/|title=Dickey Betts Looks Back: The Lost Allman Brother on Regret, Retirement|last=Browne|first=David|date=November 22, 2017|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=February 18, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200218202725/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/dickey-betts-the-lost-allman-brother-121021/|url-status=live}}</ref> He had four children: Kimberly, Christy, Jessica, and [[Duane Betts|Duane]]. Christy is married to [[Frank Hannon]] of the band [[Tesla (band)|Tesla]]. Jessica is the namesake of Betts' [[Jessica (instrumental) |instrumental]]. Duane, named for Betts' former bandmate Duane Allman, is also a musician and performed and recorded with his father, and in a band together with Gregg Allman's son Devon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180809/duane-betts-talks-album-with-devon-allman-dickey-betts-band-live-cddvd-and-aug-15-sarasota-show|title=Duane Betts talks album with Devon Allman, Dickey Betts Band live CD/DVD and Aug. 15 Sarasota show|last=Tatangelo|first=Wade|website=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|language=en|access-date=February 18, 2020|archive-date=September 29, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190929154356/https://www.heraldtribune.com/news/20180809/duane-betts-talks-album-with-devon-allman-dickey-betts-band-live-cddvd-and-aug-15-sarasota-show|url-status=live}}</ref>

Betts was a Florida native, born in [[West Palm Beach]]; though he resided briefly in Georgia during the formative years of the Allman Brothers Band, he lived in the [[Sarasota metropolitan area]] for most of his life.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Liberatore|url=http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_20957654/lib-at-large-duane-betts-and-legacy-allman|title=Lib at Large: Duane Betts and the legacy of the Allman Brothers|work=[[Marin Independent Journal]]|publisher=Marinij.com|date=June 29, 2012|access-date=July 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714210135/http://www.marinij.com/marinnews/ci_20957654/lib-at-large-duane-betts-and-legacy-allman|archive-date=July 14, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref>

===Death===
In August 2018, the 74-year old Betts suffered a mild stroke and had to cancel tour dates with his Dickey Betts Band. He was taken to the hospital and was in a critical but stable condition at a Florida hospital, following an accident at his home in [[Osprey, Florida]]. On September 20, 2018,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/dickey-betts-to-undergo-brain-surgery-following-accident/ar-BBNzI1x|title=Dickey Betts to Undergo Brain Surgery Following Accident|website=www.msn.com|language=en-US|access-date=September 20, 2018|archive-date=September 20, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180920084332/https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/dickey-betts-to-undergo-brain-surgery-following-accident/ar-BBNzI1x|url-status=live}}</ref> he successfully underwent surgery to relieve swelling on his brain. In a statement posted on his website, Betts and his family said the "outpouring of support from all over the world has been overwhelming and amazing. We are so appreciative."<ref>{{cite web|author=Tatangelo, Wade|url=https://eu.news-journalonline.com/story/news/state/2018/09/22/dickey-betts-surgery-success-in/10366942007/|title=Dickey Betts' surgery a 'success' in Sarasota|publisher=The Daytona Bach News Journal|date=September 18, 2018|accessdate=April 20, 2024}}</ref>

Betts died from cancer and [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] at his home in Osprey, Florida, on April 18, 2024, at the age of 80.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dickey Betts, Allman Brothers Band Singer-Guitarist, Dead at 80|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-band-dead-727523/|last=Browne|first=David|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=April 18, 2024|access-date=April 18, 2024|archive-date=April 18, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418154924/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/dickey-betts-allman-brothers-band-dead-727523/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Instagram |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/C56GswQuAKR/ |access-date=April 18, 2024 |website=www.instagram.com |archive-date=April 18, 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418160858/https://www.instagram.com/p/C56GswQuAKR/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

==Discography==
{{See also|The Allman Brothers Band discography}}

* ''[[Highway Call]]'' (1974) <small>(as Richard Betts)</small> [[Billboard 200|US]] 19<ref name="Whitburn Albums">{{cite book| last = Whitburn| first = Joel| title = Top Pop Albums 1955-2016| publisher = Prometheus Global Media| year = 2018| isbn = 978-0-89820-226-7}}</ref>
* ''[[Dickey Betts & Great Southern (album)|Dickey Betts & Great Southern]]'' (1977) <small>(as Dickey Betts & Great Southern)</small> US 31<ref name="Whitburn Albums"></ref>
* ''[[Atlanta's Burning Down]]'' (1978) <small>(as Dickey Betts & Great Southern)</small> US 157<ref name="Whitburn Albums"></ref>
* ''[[Pattern Disruptive]]'' (1988) <small>(as Dickey Betts Band)</small> US 187<ref name="Whitburn Albums"></ref>
* ''[[Let's Get Together (Dickey Betts Band album)|Let's Get Together]]'' (2001) <small>(as Dickey Betts Band)</small>
